column6: Variable name
column7: Intuitive description
column8: Technical description
column9: Methodological Notes
column10: Sources

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/global-wealth-inequality-on-wid-world-estimates-and-imputations-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-16/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Bajard, F., Chancel, L., Moshrif, R., Piketty, T. (2021). “Global Wealth Inequality on WID.world: Estimates and Imputations”[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

(2021), "2021 Regional DINA Update for Asia"[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.

column9: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1996: survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 1997-2001: interpolated survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2002: survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2003-2004: interpolated survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2005: survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2006-2007: interpolated survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2008: survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2009-2011: interpolated survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2012: survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2013: interpolated survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2014-2019: survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2020: extrapolated distribution + imputed nonresponse, 2021: extrapolated distribution

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1988, 1995, 2011. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017); [/URL_TEXT][/URL];[URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/2022-dina-regional-update-for-africa-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2022-06/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Updated by Robilliard (2022), "2022 DINA Regional Update for Africa"[/URL_TEXT][/URL]Before 1988, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/countries-with-regional-income-imputations-on-wid-world-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-15/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel and Piketty, “Countries with Regional Income Imputations on WID.world” (2021)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; For long run series (full population), [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/longrunpaper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, L., Piketty, T. “Global Income Inequality 1820-2020: The Persistence and Mutation of Extreme Inequality” (2021)[/URL_TEXT][/URL][URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/historical-inequality-series-on-wid-world-updates-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2023-01/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT] ; Chancel, L., Moshrif, R., Piketty, T., Xuereb, S., (2023),  "Historical Inequality Series on WID.world - Updates"[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p0p50 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2000, 2008, 2018. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.
column10: After 2000, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017); [/URL_TEXT][/URL];[URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/2022-dina-regional-update-for-africa-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2022-06/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Updated by Robilliard (2022), "2022 DINA Regional Update for Africa"[/URL_TEXT][/URL]Before 2000, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/countries-with-regional-income-imputations-on-wid-world-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-15/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel and Piketty, “Countries with Regional Income Imputations on WID.world” (2021)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column9: Fiscal income rescaled to match the macroeconomic aggregates.
column10: WID.world computations using fiscal and net national income.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/2021-dina-regional-update-for-asia-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-6/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Bajard, F., Moshrif, R. (2021), “Regional DINA Update for Asia”[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: WID.world aggregations of individual country data
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/2021-dina-regional-update-for-asia-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-6/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Bajard, F., Moshrif, R. (2021), “Regional DINA Update for Asia”[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/distributional-financial-accounts-in-europe-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-12/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Blanchet, T., Martinez-Toledano, C. (2021), Distributional Financial Accounts in Europe; [/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.

Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2003, 2011, 2015, 2018. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.
column10: After 2003, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p0p50 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1983-1988: survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 1989: interpolated survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 1990: survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 1991-2000: interpolated concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2001: survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2002-2003: interpolated survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2004: survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2005-2006: interpolated survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2007: survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2008-2010: interpolated survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2011: survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2012-2014: interpolated survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2015: survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2016-2020: extrapolated distribution + imputed nonresponse, 2021: extrapolated distribution
column10: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the US?” + Updates by Neef and Sodano (2022)

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/global-wealth-inequality-on-wid-world-estimates-and-imputations-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-16/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Bajard, F., Chancel, L., Moshrif, R., Piketty, T. (2021). “Global Wealth Inequality on WID.world: Estimates and Imputations”[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1985, 1993, 2002, 2009, 2015. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p0p50 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980-1984: survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 1985: interpolated survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 1986-1990: survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 1991: interpolated survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 1992-2003: survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2004-2005: interpolated survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2006: survey + imputed nonresponse, 2007: interpolated survey + imputed nonresponse, 2008-2019: survey + imputed nonresponse, 2020: extrapolated distribution + imputed nonresponse, 2021: extrapolated distribution
column10: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the US?” + Updates by Neef and Sodano (2022)

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1994, 1998, 2003, 2009, 2014, 2018. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2001, 2007, 2015. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column9: Fiscal income rescaled to match the macroeconomic aggregates.
column10: WID.world computations using fiscal and net national income.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1992, 2008. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2003, 2011, 2018. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.
column10: After 2003, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2004, 2014. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017); [/URL_TEXT][/URL];[URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/2022-dina-regional-update-for-africa-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2022-06/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Updated by Robilliard (2022), "2022 DINA Regional Update for Africa"[/URL_TEXT][/URL]Before 2004, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/countries-with-regional-income-imputations-on-wid-world-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-15/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel and Piketty, “Countries with Regional Income Imputations on WID.world” (2021)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/global-wealth-inequality-on-wid-world-estimates-and-imputations-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-16/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Bajard, F., Chancel, L., Moshrif, R., Piketty, T. (2021). “Global Wealth Inequality on WID.world: Estimates and Imputations”[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2004, 2014. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/global-wealth-inequality-on-wid-world-estimates-and-imputations-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-16/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Bajard, F., Chancel, L., Moshrif, R., Piketty, T. (2021). “Global Wealth Inequality on WID.world: Estimates and Imputations”[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p0p50 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1985, 1986, 1987, 1988, 1992, 1995, 1998, 2002, 2008, 2015, 2018. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.
column10: After 1985, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p0p50 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1981: survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1982-1984: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1985: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1986-1987: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1988: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1989-1990: survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1991: interpolated survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1992-2003: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2004-2015: survey + tax data, 2016-2019: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2020-2021: extrapolated distribution
column10: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the US?” + Updates by Neef and Sodano (2022)

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2004, 2012. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1981: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1982-1986: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1987: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1988-1991: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1992: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1993-1994: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1995: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1996: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1997-2002: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2003-2010: survey + tax data, 2011-2019: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2020-2021: extrapolated distribution
column10: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the US?” + Updates by Neef and Sodano (2022)

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Fiscal income rescaled to match the macroeconomic aggregates.
column10: WID.world computations using fiscal and net national income.

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2002, 2012, 2013, 2017. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p0p50 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: WID.world aggregations of individual country data

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1990, 1995, 1999, 2004, 2008, 2010, 2012, 2015, 2017. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.

Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1981, 1995, 1999, 2004, 2010, 2015. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2005, 2017. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p0p50 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.

column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1987, 1988, 1991, 1998, 2005, 2012, 2016. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1991, 1994, 2002, 2007, 2012, 2018. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1991, 1993, 2002, 2010, 2018. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.
column10: After 1991, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017); [/URL_TEXT][/URL];[URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/2022-dina-regional-update-for-africa-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2022-06/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Updated by Robilliard (2022), "2022 DINA Regional Update for Africa"[/URL_TEXT][/URL]Before 1991, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/countries-with-regional-income-imputations-on-wid-world-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-15/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel and Piketty, “Countries with Regional Income Imputations on WID.world” (2021)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/global-wealth-inequality-on-wid-world-estimates-and-imputations-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-16/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Bajard, F., Chancel, L., Moshrif, R., Piketty, T. (2021). “Global Wealth Inequality on WID.world: Estimates and Imputations”[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/global-wealth-inequality-on-wid-world-estimates-and-imputations-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-16/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Bajard, F., Chancel, L., Moshrif, R., Piketty, T. (2021). “Global Wealth Inequality on WID.world: Estimates and Imputations”[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p0p50 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/countries-with-regional-income-imputations-on-wid-world-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-15/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel and Piketty (2021), "Countries with Regional Income Imputations on WID.world"[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Fiscal income rescaled to match the macroeconomic aggregates.
column10: WID.world computations using fiscal and net national income.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column9: In 1961 and 1971 data covers rural areas only. Net wealth is reported since 1981. In 1971, net wealth is estimated using the liabilies at the bracket level (assuming individuals remain in the same bracket). In 1961, liabilities are estimated assuming the liability/gross wealth ratios at the bracket level from 1971, and using the 1971 proportions of individuals having any kind of liability. In 2002 and 2012 series are corrected using Forbes lists, and the top of the survey distribution is replaced by a Pareto distribution.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/global-wealth-inequality-on-wid-world-estimates-and-imputations-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-16/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Bajard, F., Chancel, L., Moshrif, R., Piketty, T. (2021). “Global Wealth Inequality on WID.world: Estimates and Imputations”[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column9: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1981-1986: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1987: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1988-1993: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1994-1996: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1997-1999: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2000: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2001: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2002-2003: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2004-2015: survey + tax data, 2016-2019: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2020-2021: extrapolated distribution
column10: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the US?” + Updates by Neef and Sodano (2022)

The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1992, 1994, 1997, 2005, 2015. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p0p50 group. column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
column9: The inheritance tax data for 2008-2009 was not used here because of inconsistency of figures in the data. The amount of net personal wealth estimated here is much less than the net household wealth in the National Balance Sheets. The difference could be explained as follows. First, the net household wealth in the National Balance Sheets includes the asset of non-profit sector. Second, the estimate of net personal wealth covers only real estate and financial assets, while other kinds of assets are included in the National Balance Sheets. Third, while the real estates in the National Balance Sheets are those in market prices, they are in government appraisal values, lower than market prices. Considering the share of real estate in the net household wealth is 76% (the average in 2000-2013)  and the total amount in government appraisal values is 67% of that in market prices, the net household wealth would be underestimated as much as 25% at least from the difference in government appraisal values and market prices of real estate.
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/wealth-inequality-in-korea-2000-2013-journal-of-the-korean-welfare-state-and-social-policy-2018/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kim, Nak Nyeon(2018), Wealth Inequality in Korea, 2000-2013: Evidence from Inheritance Tax Statistics; [/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1986, 1994, 2002, 2017. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
column9: WID.world aggregations of individual country data
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/global-wealth-inequality-on-wid-world-estimates-and-imputations-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-16/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Bajard, F., Chancel, L., Moshrif, R., Piketty, T. (2021). “Global Wealth Inequality on WID.world: Estimates and Imputations”[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: WID.world aggregations of individual country data
