column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1980, 1993, 1997, 1999, 2001, 2005, 2010, 2012. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1997, 2004, 2010, 2016, 2019. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.
column10: After 1997, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/distributional-financial-accounts-in-europe-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-12/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Blanchet, T., Martinez-Toledano, C. (2021), Distributional Financial Accounts in Europe; [/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 2006-2013: survey + imputed nonresponse, 2014-2019: survey + concept correction + imputed nonresponse, 2020: extrapolated distribution + imputed nonresponse, 2021: extrapolated distribution
column10: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the US?” + Updates by Neef and Sodano (2022)

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1987, 1993, 1995, 2000, 2004, 2008, 2014. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2006, 2012, 2017. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults

The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1984, 1990, 1998, 2000, 2006, 2013. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/global-wealth-inequality-on-wid-world-estimates-and-imputations-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-16/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Bajard, F., Chancel, L., Moshrif, R., Piketty, T. column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/global-wealth-inequality-on-wid-world-estimates-and-imputations-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-16/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Bajard, F., Chancel, L., Moshrif, R., Piketty, T. (2021). “Global Wealth Inequality on WID.world: Estimates and Imputations”[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p0p50 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2003, 2009, 2015. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Fiscal income rescaled to match the macroeconomic aggregates.
column10: WID.world computations using fiscal and net national income.

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p0p50 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1992, 1994, 2005, 2007, 2011, 2014, 2018. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Fiscal income rescaled to match the macroeconomic aggregates.
column10: WID.world computations using fiscal and net national income.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/dina-update-for-asia-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2020-08/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Updated by Jenmana, Moshrif and Yang (2020), "Regional DINA Update for Asia"; [/URL_TEXT][/URL][URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/2021-dina-regional-update-for-asia-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-6/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Updated by Bajard, F. and Moshrif, R. (2021), "2021 Regional DINA Update for Asia"[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1983-1989: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1990-1991: survey + concept correction + interpolated tax data, 1992-2004: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2005-2015: survey + tax data, 2016-2019: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2020-2021: extrapolated distribution
column10: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the US?” + Updates by Neef and Sodano (2022)

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/wealth-inequality-in-interwar-poland/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]For 1923, Wroński, M. (2021), Distributional Financial Accounts in Europe; [/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1989-2006: survey + concept correction + extrapolated nonresponse, 2007-2013: survey + extrapolated nonresponse, 2014: interpolated survey + tax data, 2015: interpolated survey + extrapolated nonresponse, 2016-2019: survey + extrapolated nonresponse, 2020: extrapolated distribution + extrapolated nonresponse, 2021: extrapolated distribution
column10: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the US?” + Updates by Neef and Sodano (2022)

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1984, 2000, 2005, 2010, 2013, 2016. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2000, 2010. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p0p50 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1991, 1994, 2001, 2005, 2011, 2018. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017); [/URL_TEXT][/URL];[URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/2022-dina-regional-update-for-africa-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2022-06/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Updated by Robilliard (2022), "2022 DINA Regional Update for Africa"[/URL_TEXT][/URL]Before 1989, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/countries-with-regional-income-imputations-on-wid-world-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-15/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel and Piketty, “Countries with Regional Income Imputations on WID.world” (2021)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/dina-update-for-asia-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2020-08/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Updated by Jenmana, Moshrif and Yang (2020), "Regional DINA Update for Asia"; [/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p0p50 group. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.

column10: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/dina-update-for-asia-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2020-08/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Updated by Jenmana, Moshrif and Yang (2020), "Regional DINA Update for Asia"; [/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2017. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2009, 2016. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.
column10: After 2009, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017); [/URL_TEXT][/URL];[URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/2022-dina-regional-update-for-africa-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2022-06/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Updated by Robilliard (2022), "2022 DINA Regional Update for Africa"[/URL_TEXT][/URL]Before 2009, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/countries-with-regional-income-imputations-on-wid-world-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-15/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel and Piketty, “Countries with Regional Income Imputations on WID.world” (2021)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

Surveys are available for the following years: 2009, 2016. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.
column10: After 2009, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017); [/URL_TEXT][/URL];[URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/2022-dina-regional-update-for-africa-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2022-06/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Updated by Robilliard (2022), "2022 DINA Regional Update for Africa"[/URL_TEXT][/URL]Before 2009, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/countries-with-regional-income-imputations-on-wid-world-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-15/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel and Piketty, “Countries with Regional Income Imputations on WID.world” (2021)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p0p50 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2009, 2014. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1994, 2000, 2009, 2016. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

A Contrast Between Continental European and English-Speaking Countries, OUP, 2007[/URL_TEXT][/URL]After 1980, [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/why-is-europe-more-equal-than-the-united-states-world-inequality-lab-wp-2020-19/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the US?”[/URL_TEXT][/URL][URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/2022-dina-regional-update-for-europe-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2022-02/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT] Updated by Neef and Sodano (2022), “2022 DINA Regional Update for Europe”[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1991, 2000, 2007, 2011, 2017. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1991, 2000, 2007, 2011, 2017. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 2006, 2011, 2015, 2018. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1989, 1992, 1996, 1999, 2002, 2005, 2009, 2012, 2016, 2019. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.

column10: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the US?” + Updates by Neef and Sodano (2022); For long run series (full population), [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/longrunpaper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, L., Piketty, T. “Global Income Inequality 1820-2020: The Persistence and Mutation of Extreme Inequality” (2021)[/URL_TEXT][/URL][URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/historical-inequality-series-on-wid-world-updates-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2023-01/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT] ; Chancel, L., Moshrif, R., Piketty, T., Xuereb, S., (2023),  "Historical Inequality Series on WID.world - Updates"[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p0p50 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1981-1985: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1986: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1987-1990: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1991: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1992-1993: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1994-2005: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2006-2014: survey + tax data, 2015-2019: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2020-2021: extrapolated distribution

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.

The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p0p50 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Fiscal income rescaled to match the macroeconomic aggregates.
column10: WID.world computations using fiscal and net national income.

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
column9: WID.world aggregations of individual country data
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/global-wealth-inequality-on-wid-world-estimates-and-imputations-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-16/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Bajard, F., Chancel, L., Moshrif, R., Piketty, T. column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

column6: Pre-tax national income. Share Adults. tax unit
column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Fiscal income rescaled to match the macroeconomic aggregates.
column10: WID.world computations using fiscal and net national income.

The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]

column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p0p50 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.

column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1991, 1993, 1996, 1998, 2002, 2004, 2006, 2010, 2015. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.
column10: After 1991, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? column7: Pre-tax national income share held by the p90p100 group. Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
column8: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
column9: Figures are obtained by correcting survey tabulations provided by the World Bank (PovcalNet) to account for conceptual discrepancies and the underrepresentation of top incomes. Surveys are available for the following years: 1991, 1993, 1996, 1998, 2002, 2004, 2006, 2010, 2015. Income shares are interpolated linearly when surveys are available at the beginning and at the end of a given period. Inequality series are extrapolated backwards to 1990 and forwards to 2019 by keeping income shares constant when no data is available for these years.
column10: After 1991, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/cgm2019-full-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Cogneau, Gethin & Myczkowski (2019), How large are African Inequalities? Towards Distributional National Accounts in Africa (1990-2017); [/URL_TEXT][/URL];[URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/2022-dina-regional-update-for-africa-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2022-06/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Updated by Robilliard (2022), "2022 DINA Regional Update for Africa"[/URL_TEXT][/URL]Before 1991, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/countries-with-regional-income-imputations-on-wid-world-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-15/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel and Piketty, “Countries with Regional Income Imputations on WID.world” (2021)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column6: Net personal wealth. Share Adults. equal-split adults
column7: Net personal wealth share held by the p90p100 group. Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them. The population is comprised of individuals over age 20. The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
column8: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
column10: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/global-wealth-inequality-on-wid-world-estimates-and-imputations-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2021-16/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Bajard, F., Chancel, L., Moshrif, R., Piketty, T. (2021). “Global Wealth Inequality on WID.world: Estimates and Imputations”[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

column9: Fiscal income rescaled to match the macroeconomic aggregates.
column10: WID.world computations using fiscal and net national income.
